setContent.text:
Evaluating Information

You can find almost anything on the Internet, but not all of that information is of high quality, and not all of it is appropriate for your assignments.

This tutorial will guide you through the process of evaluating sources of information. The goal is to help you select the best sources for your academic papers and projects.

Peer Review?

Peer review is a process by which scholarly articles are vetted for publication. Approval by an editor is usually all that is required for an article to be published in a popular or trade magazine, but a scholarly journal will require that an article be reviewed by experts in the field before it is published.

Test Yourself: Popular Periodicals

Which of the following is most likely to be a popular periodical? Tap the info icons to see cover images.

answers.response: Incorrect. Even if you know nothing about this journal, you can guess that something with the name of an academic field in the title will be scholarly.
answers.infoLabel: Cover of The American Journal of Botany

answers.response: Incorrect. Do you know what "isotachophoresis" is? We don’t either, so it’s probably a scholarly journal.
Incorrect. Even if you know nothing about this journal, you can guess that something with the name of an academic field in the title will be scholarly.
answers.infoLabel: Cover of Art History and Criticism

answers.response: Correct! Rolling Stone is a popular periodical. It appeals to a very general readership, covering all aspects of popular culture. Celebrity interviews are a sure sign of a popular journal.

Test Yourself: Plagiarism

Your art history instructor has assigned a paper in which you need to select a painting for analysis. You find a Van Gogh painting online by using Google Images. Do you need to cite the source of this image?

answers.text: Yes. I didn't paint it, so I have to cite it.
No. Anyone can find it on Google, so why cite?
answers.response: No. You didn’t paint it, so you have to cite it. Citation is about crediting the creator of a work, not just about how to find something.

setContent.text: You're writing a paper on the pros and cons of legalizing recreational marijuana. Please order the following sources from most to least appropriate for your project.

items.name: Legalizing Marijuana: A Shift in Policies Across America, a book by Nancy E. Marion, Professor of Political Science at the University of Akron, 2016
"The New Model for a Health-First Approach to Legalizing Weed," article in The Atlantic by staff writer James Hamblin, June 22, 2018
The website for the Marijuana Policy Project, an organization dedicated to regulating marijuana use similar to alcohol and educating readers about marijuana
Evergreen: The Road to Legalization, a documentary that investigates the "absurdity" of medical marijuana prohibition, 2018
A scholarly article, "The Impact of Marijuana Legalization on Adolescent Use, Consequences, and Perceived Risk" by Ashley Estoup in Substance Use & Misuse, 2016

setContent.perfectResponse: Yes, you got the order right
setContent.goodResponse: Your response is very similar to ours! See the numbers in the circles for the way that we ordered the sources.
setContent.badResponse: Not quite. See the numbers in the circles for the way that we ordered the sources.
